Award.AwardTitle: Applications and extensions of p-adic Hodge theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Number theory is one of the oldest of all branches of mathematics, with its first important results dating back more than two millennia. While whole numbers are in a sense discrete objects, in modern times they are often studied using techniques of continuous mathematics, such as calculus. The PI's work focuses in particular on the use of p-adic numbers, which were introduced early in the 20th century as a number system analogous to the real numbers, but recording information about divisibility of integers. In addition to theoretical results, the p-adic numbers give rise to computational techniques with some relevance in computer science, especially in modern cryptography.

Building on recent breakthroughs in p-adic Hodge theory, we extend the field in several different directions. We extend the theory of p-adic representations to allow coefficients in larger rings, with an eye towards applications to the p-adic interpolation of automorphic forms. We also allow the replacement of p-adic Galois groups with etale fundamental groups; this is expected to shed new light on the p-adic Langlands correspondence. Finally, we consider ways to replace the p-adic numbers with the full ring of integers; this involves systematic use of Witt vectors over arbitrary rings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Arithmetic geometry is the study of polynomial equations with integer (whole number) coefficients, and the solutions of same. It is one of the oldest branches of mathematics, having clear roots in ancient Babylonia, Greece, India, and China. In modern times, it has come into increasing contact with computer science; in particular, public-key cryptography is largely based on constructions from arithmetic geometry, such as elliptic curves.

In the early 20th century, a new tool became available for the study of arithmetic geometry: the p-adic numbers, a number system that formally simulates the real numbers, but replaces usual notions of size with a metric based on divisibility by a particular prime number p. (That is to say, there are infinitely many such number systems: a 2-adic one, a 3-adic one, a 5-adic one, etc.) Using the p-adic numbers, it is possible to transport many concept from "continuous" mathematics (i.e., calculus) into a setting where they have concrete consequences for arithmetic geometry. Notably, in the early 1960, Bernard Dwork discovered that the classical theory of ordinary differential equations could be exploited to control the number of solutions of a system of polynomial equations modulo a prime; more recently, the PI and others have exploited these ideas to develop computer software to make efficient counts of such solutions (with applications to both arithmetic geometry and cryptography). Somewhat surprisingly, the information flow also operates in reverse; some results of the PI on classical differential equations have been inspired by an analogy with earlier results on p-adic differential equations.

In the 21th century, work of the PI and others has given rise to an even newer, more powerful tool: the theory of perfectoid spaces. Perfectoid spaces arise from classical spaces by a certain infinite process, akin to folding a piece of paper in half infinitely many times. The resulting theory provides a dictionary for translating ideas and results between two largely distinct geometric frameworks: "zero characteristic", which more closely resembles classical geometry, and "positive characteristic", which appears when working with polynomial equations modulo a prime.

Using the theory of perfectoid spaces, the PI and other researchers have settled a number of long-standing problems in arithmetic geometry; discovered exotic new constructions that are likely to shed further light on some old questions; and inched closer towards a comprehensive understanding of the behavior of certain objects (L-functions) that lie at the heart of the subject, and which play a role in some of the most fundamental open problems in the subject (e.g., the Riemann Hypothesis). It is likely that the role of perfectoid spaces in arithmetic geometry will continue to expand in the coming decades, and the PI plans to continue his foundational research on the topic.

Broader impacts of this project can be seen in several areas. As noted above, there are some links between arithmetic geometry and computer science, and some of the PI's research sits at this boundary. The project also includes various forms of professional development for graduate students, including one-on-one mentoring, training through courses and reading seminars, production of expository materials, and organization of instructional conferences (e.g., the Arizona Winter School, with over 250 graduate student participants per year). Finally, the PI is committed to expanding the population that participates in research mathematics, particularly through his service on the board of directors of the Art of Problem Solving Initiative and oversight of that organization's Bridge to Enter Advanced Mathematics program. BEAM seeks to build a viable pipeline, starting at the middle school level, for underserved students with exceptional potential in mathematics to develop a passion for knowledge that will carry them into the next generation of STEM leadership.
